quiz.name: Module 1: Portfolio Risk and Return: Part I
quiz.subtopic: Module 1: Portfolio Risk and Return: Part I

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06816
entry.itemBody: An equally weighted portfolio is composed of two risky assets. If the correlation of asset returns is equal to zero, the portfolio standard deviation is:

answerFeedback.2e6db318-a497-4fc6-86d9-4449fbd75eea: Incorrect because the portfolio's standard deviation is simply a weighted average of the standard deviations of the two assets when the correlation of asset returns is equal to one.
answerFeedback.4a929c31-a733-4201-921c-bddba7f11a15: Incorrect because the portfolio risk is less than the weighted average of risks when the correlation of asset returns is less than one. For an equally weighted portfolio, the standard deviation can only be equal to zero when the two assets are perfectly negatively correlated (ρ = –1) and the two assets have the same standard deviation. For an extreme case in which ρ12 = –1 (that is, the two asset returns move in opposite directions), the portfolio can be made risk free.
answerFeedback.a4419085-56b0-4329-b754-f02b1fb05fb3: Correct because the portfolio risk is less than the weighted average of risks when the correlation of asset returns is less than one.

choices.itemBody: B. equal to the weighted average of the assets' standard deviations.
C. less than the weighted average of the assets' standard deviations.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Tomter-04
entry.itemBody: When creating a long-only portfolio, which of the following correlation coefficients between assets would be most effective at reducing portfolio risk?

answerFeedback.5e245cd0-a600-490d-a15b-6cf7c700e26c: Incorrect because the correlation coefficient is not the lowest of the three options. The closer the correlation coefficient is to –1, the greater the reduction in portfolio risk. Portfolio risk falls when the two assets are not perfectly correlated (ρ12 < +1). Sufficiently low values of the correlation coefficient can make the portfolio riskless under certain conditions. For an extreme case in which ρ12 = –1 (that is, the two asset returns move in opposite directions), the portfolio can be made risk free.
answerFeedback.8b4b31fa-b72c-4b49-b47f-73c781a748df: Incorrect because the correlation coefficient is not the lowest of the three options. The closer the correlation coefficient is to –1, the greater the reduction in portfolio risk. Portfolio risk falls when the two assets are not perfectly correlated (ρ12 < +1). Sufficiently low values of the correlation coefficient can make the portfolio riskless under certain conditions. For an extreme case in which ρ12 = –1 (that is, the two asset returns move in opposite directions), the portfolio can be made risk free.
answerFeedback.de1220b8-cb42-4b6e-9005-f0de965bf580: Correct because –0.5 is the smallest of the three correlations and the closer the correlation coefficient is to –1, the greater the reduction in portfolio risk. The correlation coefficient between two assets determines the effect on portfolio risk when the two assets are combined. You will find that portfolio risk is unaffected when the two assets are perfectly correlated (ρ12 = +1). In other words, the portfolio's standard deviation is simply a weighted average of the standard deviations of the two assets and as such a portfolio's risk is unchanged with the addition of assets with the same risk parameters. Portfolio risk falls, however, when the two assets are not perfectly correlated (ρ12 < +1). Sufficiently low values of the correlation coefficient can make the portfolio riskless under certain conditions. For an extreme case in which ρ12 = –1 (that is, the two asset returns move in opposite directions), the portfolio can be made risk free. Analytically, the standard deviation risk of a two asset portfolio is given by the square root of the portfolio's variance: σP = (w12σ12 + w22σ22 + 2w1w2ρ12σ1σ2)1/2, which is a strictly increasing function of ρ12. Hence, –0.5, the smallest of the three correlations, has the lowest risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Conover-07
entry.itemBody: For a risk-seeking investor, an investment in a risk-free asset generates utility that is:

answerFeedback.0c58a9ec-fcdc-4180-abdc-41d0d8db7674: Incorrect because a risk-free asset (σ2 = 0) generates the same utility for all individuals.
answerFeedback.87ced430-2790-45de-b1ae-94bcb20ad6d6: Incorrect because a risk-free asset (σ2 = 0) generates the same utility for all individuals.
answerFeedback.c0d05bfd-05f8-4709-8c7d-69b0ae70f466: Correct because a risk-free asset (σ2 = 0) generates the same utility for all individuals. If σ2 = 0, then U = E(r) - 1/2(A)(σ2 ) = E(r) for all individuals.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the utility generated for a risk-averse investor.
B. equal to the utility generated for a risk-averse investor.
C. greater than the utility generated for a risk-averse investor.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Gottschalk-07
entry.itemBody: The Markowitz efficient frontier is best described as a curve that:

answerFeedback.59825e61-a924-4155-89e5-7c1da29bed32: Incorrect because the curve that lies above and to the right of the global minimum-variance portfolio is referred to as the Markowitz efficient frontier because it contains all portfolios of risky assets that rational, risk-averse investors will choose. The efficient frontier is the upper part of the minimum-variance frontier, it does not lie above and to the left of it.
answerFeedback.e464e775-4f22-4505-9688-da7295354a40: Incorrect because the entire collection of minimum-variance portfolios for all possible returns is referred to as the minimum-variance frontier, not the efficient frontier (which is only the upper arm of the minimum-variance frontier). Compared to the investment opportunity set, the minimum-variance frontier defines the smaller set of portfolios in which investors would want to invest. Note that no risk-averse investor will choose to invest in a portfolio to the right of the minimum-variance frontier because a portfolio on the minimum-variance frontier can give the same return but at a lower risk.
answerFeedback.ea30159b-e4e9-4b54-8d4e-9cf48f199300: Correct because the Markowitz efficient frontier contains all portfolios of risky assets that rational, risk-averse investors will choose.

choices.itemBody: A. lies above and to the left of the minimum-variance frontier.
B. connects the minimum-variance portfolios for all possible returns.
C. contains all portfolios of risky assets that rational, risk-averse investors will choose.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Croitoru-06
entry.itemBody: Long-term historical data on the risk–return trade-off of securities show that investors are most likely:

answerFeedback.01954b57-cdfc-4fea-b833-0623b2caf2ca: Correct because the expression 'risk–return trade-off' refers to the positive relationship between expected risk and return. In other words, a higher return is not possible to attain in efficient markets and over long periods of time without accepting higher risk. Expected returns should be greater for assets with greater risk. Over long periods of time, we observe that higher risk does result in higher mean returns. Thus, it is reasonable to claim that, over the long term, market prices reward higher risk with higher returns, which is a characteristic of a risk-averse investor.
answerFeedback.4caeb008-226f-44e7-9ff1-dd2975cd1a73: Incorrect because because long-term historical data on securities suggest that investors are risk averse, not risk seeking.
answerFeedback.e9516dbc-7786-48de-9818-eb75f5ac0133: Incorrect because long-term historical data on securities suggest that investors are risk averse, not risk neutral.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Gagne-09
entry.itemBody: When evaluating the return distribution of an asset class, the probability of extreme returns is best assessed by the distribution's:

answerFeedback.3a6950ec-02d7-4caa-a109-b35c017d1c35: Correct because in evaluating investments using only the mean (expected return) and variance (risk), we are implicitly making two important assumptions: 1) that the returns are normally distributed and can be fully characterized by their means and variances and 2) that markets are not only informationally efficient but that they are also operationally efficient. To the extent that these assumptions are violated, we need to consider additional investment characteristics. One of them is kurtosis. Kurtosis refers to fat tails or higher than normal probabilities for extreme returns and has the effect of increasing an asset’s risk that is not captured in a mean–variance framework. This applies to asset returns as several market participants note that the probability and the magnitude of extreme events is underappreciated and was a primary contributing factor to the financial crisis of 2008.
answerFeedback.8d55a676-5fa8-4a64-a864-e497e1292d32: Incorrect because using only mean and variance would be appropriate to evaluate investments if returns were distributed normally. Returns, however, are not normally distributed...because the probability of extreme events is significantly greater than what a normal distribution would suggest. The latter deviation is referred to as kurtosis.
answerFeedback.cb605b30-c5a8-4152-af9d-427eb48385a7: Incorrect because skewness refers to asymmetry of the return distribution, that is, returns are not symmetric around the mean. Skewness does not refer specifically to the probability of extreme events (and does not measure it) even though a negatively skewed distribution would have a longer left tail relative to the normal distribution.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Chua-04
entry.itemBody: With respect to capital market theory, which of the following statements is most accurate?

answerFeedback.1027ce98-a254-4018-a62c-34b4d8d9d577: Incorrect because the optimal risky portfolio is selected from numerous risky portfolios without considering the investor’s preferences.
answerFeedback.b131b7d7-147b-4c67-b93c-a03c2dddcfab: Correct because, for a given Markowitz efficient frontier, a different risk-free rate will result in a different tangent to the frontier, hence a different optimal risky portfolio. CAL(P) is the optimal capital allocation line and Portfolio P is the optimal risky portfolio. Thus, with the addition of the risk-free asset, we are able to narrow our selection of risky portfolios to a single optimal risky portfolio, P, which is at the tangent of CAL(P) and the efficient frontier of risky assets.
answerFeedback.b3672f31-f07e-4d01-8240-fb2ddf69ab78: Incorrect because all investors regardless of taste, risk preferences, and initial wealth will hold a combination of two portfolios or funds: a risk-free asset and an optimal portfolio of risky assets. The investor's optimal portfolio thus lies on the capital allocation line (CAL), not on the Markowitz efficient frontier. If it is optimal for an investor to allocate no wealth to the risk-free asset, the investor's optimal portfolio will lie on the Markowitz efficient frontier. However, this is not 'always' the case.

choices.itemBody: A. The optimal risky portfolio is dependent on the risk-free rate.
B. The optimal risky portfolio is dependent on the investor's risk profile.
C. The investor's optimal portfolio must lie on the Markowitz efficient frontier.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Huffman-10
entry.itemBody: Two investors have indifference curves that are tangent to the same capital allocation line (CAL). If Investor 1 is more risk averse than Investor 2, Investor 1's optimal portfolio is:

answerFeedback.12606947-660b-4bc2-852a-f72bfb835bc9: Correct because the optimal portfolio maximizes the return per unit of risk (as it is on the capital allocation line), and it simultaneously supplies the investor with the most satisfaction (utility).
answerFeedback.a5257470-d157-4459-bc8c-01bbc963380b:
Incorrect because the less risk-averse investor is willing to accept the additional risk.

Therefore, the more risk-averse Investor 1 will have an optimal portfolio with less risk and a lower expected return than Investor 2. The optimal portfolio maximizes the return per unit of risk (as it is on the capital allocation line), and it simultaneously supplies the investor with the most satisfaction (utility).
answerFeedback.f53eaf02-de5b-4748-8264-1d8b4c37b1ad: Incorrect because, as the investors have different degrees of risk aversion, they will not have the same optimal portfolio. The optimal portfolio maximizes the return per unit of risk (as it is on the capital allocation line), and it simultaneously supplies the investor with the most satisfaction (utility).

choices.itemBody: A. to the left of Investor 2's optimal portfolio on the CAL.
B. at the same point on the CAL as Investor 2's optimal portfolio.
C. to the right of Investor 2's optimal portfolio on the CAL.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09028
entry.itemBody: As the number of assets in an equally weighted portfolio becomes large, the portfolio's variance of returns most likely approaches:

answerFeedback.4535caaf-c109-46d0-9a6e-5e893c3a8ad4: Incorrect because for portfolios with a large number of assets, covariance among the assets accounts for almost all of the portfolio's risk.
answerFeedback.a9dde8c8-2458-49dd-ade6-ca60469166c6: Correct because, given equal weights and average variance/covariance (denoted σ2 and Cov, respectively), we can rewrite the portfolio variance as σP2 = σ2/N + [(N – 1)/N]Cov. The equation shows that as N becomes large, the first term on the right side with the denominator of N becomes smaller and smaller, implying that the contribution of one asset's variance to portfolio variance gradually becomes negligible. The second term, however, approaches the average covariance as N increases. It is reasonable to say that for portfolios with a large number of assets, covariance among the assets accounts for almost all of the portfolio's risk.
answerFeedback.b3426482-f9e5-4fb5-84a3-2161daed5967: Incorrect because the contribution of the average variance of the individual assets to the total portfolio variance becomes negligible as the number of assets becomes large. Furthermore, for portfolios with a large number of assets, covariance among the assets accounts for almost all of the portfolio's risk.

choices.itemBody: B. the average variance of the individual assets' returns.
C. the average covariance between the individual assets' returns.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04542
entry.itemBody: The global minimum-variance portfolio is a portfolio that lies:

answerFeedback.4221acb5-ad45-4fcd-b013-4c61b3218e4e: Incorrect because the entire collection of these minimum-variance portfolios is referred to as the minimum-variance frontier. This describes the minimum variance portfolio, but not the global minimum-variance portfolio.
answerFeedback.7be03f2f-26ed-4904-a9c0-8a142c1614c7: Correct because the left-most point on the minimum-variance frontier is the portfolio with the minimum variance among all portfolios of risky assets, and is referred to as the global minimum-variance portfolio.
answerFeedback.87095059-faac-4d13-abda-65e6e6048dec: Incorrect because the upper right-most point of the minimum-variance frontier is the opposite position of the global minimum-variance portfolio, it is actually the maximum variance on the curve of risky portfolios.

choices.itemBody: B. at the left-most point of the minimum-variance frontier.
C. at the upper right-most point of the minimum-variance frontier.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04235
entry.itemBody: The correlation of returns between two securities with equal standard deviation of returns is 0.75. If the covariance of returns is 5.5%2, the standard deviation of returns for each security is closest to:

answerFeedback.1e09b0f0-41fc-47f9-b269-fd6fb8ab5fd2: Correct because the correlation between the returns of the two securities is  r u .. = Cov u .. σ i σ j ;   σiσj = Cov u .. r u .. ;  σiσj = 5.5 0.75 =  7.3. Since the two securities have equal risk, σi = σj, σi2 = 7.3, σi = 2.7%.
answerFeedback.940afa47-1421-4565-a877-d1d4e1257eff: Incorrect because it is a miscalculation and mistakes σiσj as 2 × σi; σiσj = 5.5 0.75 = 7.3 ; 2 × σi = 7.33%; σi = 3.67% ≈ 3.7%.
answerFeedback.c05cefec-3d4b-4479-8218-f26bca03cee3: Incorrect because it is an intermediate step in the correct calculation; σiσj = 5.5 0.75 = 7.3%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01144
entry.itemBody:
A portfolio consisting of two securities has the following characteristics:

Security Portfolio Weight Standard Deviation
1 40% 15%
2 60% 18%

If the correlation of returns between the two securities is 0.20, the portfolio's standard deviation of returns is closest to:

answerFeedback.748e171a-5084-4e8b-a449-b22f2ce799ae:
Incorrect because it uses standard deviations instead of variances in the formula for the portfolio standard deviation:

w12σ1+w22σ2+2w1w2σ1σ2ρ1,2

= (0.4)2(0.15) + (0.6)2(0.18) + 2(0.4)(0.6)(0.20)(0.15)(0.18)

= (0.024) + (0.0648) + (0.002592)

= 0.091392 ≈ 9.1%.
answerFeedback.ff3a8282-db96-4e61-85d3-0db315d5dead:
Incorrect because it is portfolio variance instead of standard deviation:

w12σ12+w22σ22+2w1w2ρ1,2σ1σ2

= (0.4)2(0.15)2 + (0.6)2(0.18)2 + 2(0.4)(0.6)(0.2)(0.15)(0.18)

= (0.16)(0.0225) + (0.36)(0.0324) + (0.002592) = 0.017856 ≈ 1.8%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04639
entry.itemBody: A risk-neutral investor most likely seeks to maximize:

answerFeedback.af98c0a0-a4ef-46fc-9208-b3ad6f7b06ac: Correct because a risk-neutral investor would maximize return irrespective of risk. This is because such an investor cares only about return and not about risk, so higher return investments are more desirable even if they come with higher risk.
answerFeedback.d017a4f3-0624-4d06-a03d-9d4e2799ff6b: Incorrect because a risk-seeking investor would maximize both risk and return. A risk-neutral investor maximizes return irrespective of risk. That is, a risk-neutral investor deliberately seeks to maximize only return, not risk. It is possible that a risk-neutral investor could end up maximizing risk by maximizing return, but he only seeks to maximize return and risk is not a consideration.
answerFeedback.d5ff8d5d-7d2f-4c54-958d-999a531d990c: Incorrect because only risk-averse investors want to minimize their risk for the same amount of return, and maximize their return for the same amount of risk. A risk-neutral investor seeks to maximize return irrespective of risk, not for a given level of risk.

choices.itemBody: C. return for a given level of risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10292
entry.itemBody:
Two assets have the following characteristics:

Variance of returns for Asset 1 0.05
Variance of returns for Asset 2 0.06
Correlation of returns between Asset 1 and Asset 2 0.75

The variance of returns for an equally weighted portfolio of the two assets is closest to:

answerFeedback.3f398820-26a6-4908-99c1-6d3e48dc88d3: Incorrect because it is the weighted average of the asset variances: (0.5)(0.05) + (0.5)(0.06) = 0.025 + 0.03 = 0.055. However, a weighted average calculation is only appropriate for the portfolio standard deviation (not variance) when the correlation among assets is 1.
answerFeedback.5f52fbc0-8759-4dce-9464-03197f933d64:
Incorrect because the last term has not been doubled, leading to:

σ2p = (0.5)2(0.05) + (0.5)2(0.06) + (0.5)(0.5)(0.75)(0.05)0.5(0.06)0.5 = 0.0125 + 0.015 + 0.0102698 = 0.03777 ≈ 0.038.
answerFeedback.ed1ad6a9-0f38-4986-b877-34a6aa1d184d:
Correct because for a two asset portfolio, the expression for portfolio variance simplifies to the following using correlation:

σ2p = w12σ12 + w22σ22 + 2w1w2ρ12σ1σ2, where wi is the weight of asset i in the portfolio, σi2 is the variance of asset i, and ρij is the correlation between the returns of assets i and j. Here,

σ2p = (0.5)2(0.05) + (0.5)2(0.06) + 2(0.5)(0.5)(0.75)(0.05)0.5(0.06)0.5 = 0.0125 + 0.015 + 0.0205396 = 0.04804 ≈ 0.048.

entry.title: CFA0159-s08-Q1

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Brokerage commissions are negotiated with the brokerage firm. A security’s liquidity impacts the operational efficiency of trading costs. Specifically, liquidity impacts the bid–ask spread and can impact the stock price (if the ability to sell the stock is impaired by the uncertainty associated with being able to sell the stock).

entry.itemBody: With respect to trading costs, liquidity is least likely to impact the:

entry.title: CFA0159-s09-Q1

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Historical data over long periods of time indicate that there exists a positive risk–return relationship, which is a reflection of an investor’s risk aversion.

entry.itemBody: Evidence of risk aversion is best illustrated by a risk–return relationship that is:

entry.title: CFA0159-s10-Q6

feedback.neutral: A is correct. A risk-free asset has a variance of zero and is not dependent on whether the investor is risk neutral, risk seeking or risk averse. That is, given that the utility function of an investment is expressed as U = E ( r ) − 1 2 A σ 2 , where A is the measure of risk aversion, then the sign of A is irrelevant if the variance is zero (like that of a risk-free asset).

entry.itemBody: With respect to risk-averse investors, a risk-free asset will generate a numerical utility that is:

choices.itemBody: A. the same for all individuals.
C. equal to zero for risk seeking investors.

entry.title: CFA0159-s10-Q7

feedback.neutral: C is correct. The most risk-averse investor has the indifference curve with the greatest slope.

entry.itemBody: With respect to utility theory, the most risk-averse investor will have an indifference curve with the:

entry.title: CFA0159-s10-Q8

feedback.neutral: A is correct. A negative value in the given utility function indicates that the investor is a risk seeker.

entry.itemBody: With respect to an investor’s utility function expressed as: U = E ( r ) − 1 2 A σ 2 , which of the following values for the measure for risk aversion has the least amount of risk aversion?

entry.itemBody: If an investor’s utility function is expressed as U = E ( r ) − 1 2 A σ 2 and the measure for risk aversion has a value of 4, the risk-averse investor is most likely to choose:

entry.title: CFA0159-s11-Q1

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The CAL is the combination of the risk-free asset with zero risk and the portfolio of all risky assets that provides for the set of feasible investments. Allowing for borrowing at the risk-free rate and investing in the portfolio of all risky assets provides for attainable portfolios that dominate risky assets below the CAL.

entry.itemBody: With respect to the mean–variance portfolio theory, the capital allocation line, CAL, is the combination of the risk-free asset and a portfolio of all:

entry.title: CFA0159-s11-Q2

feedback.neutral: B is correct. The CAL represents the set of all feasible investments. Each investor’s indifference curve determines the optimal combination of the risk-free asset and the portfolio of all risky assets, which must lie on the CAL.

entry.itemBody: Two individual investors with different levels of risk aversion will have optimal portfolios that are:

choices.itemBody: A. below the capital allocation line.
B. on the capital allocation line.
C. above the capital allocation line.

entry.title: CFA0159-s12-P_Q1

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The asset’s returns are not used to calculate the portfolio’s variance [only the assets’ weights, standard deviations (or variances), and covariances (or correlations) are used].

entry.itemBody: With respect to capital market theory, which of the following asset characteristics is least likely to impact the variance of an investor’s equally weighted portfolio?

choices.itemBody: B. Standard deviation of the asset.
C. Covariances of the asset with the other assets in the portfolio.

entry.title: CFA0159-s12-P_Q2

feedback.neutral:
C is correct.

σ p o r t = w 1 2 σ 1 2 + w 2 2 σ 2 2 + 2 w 1 w 2 ρ 1 , 2 σ 1 σ 2 = ( 0.3 ) 2 ( 20 % ) 2 + ( 0.7 ) 2 ( 12 % ) 2 + 2 ( 0.3 ) ( 0.7 ) ( 0.40 ) ( 20 % ) ( 12 % ) =   ( 0.3600 % + 0.7056 % + 0.4032 % ) 0.5 = ( 1.4688 % ) 0.5 = 12.11 %

entry.itemBody:
A portfolio manager creates the following portfolio:

Security Security Weight (%) Expected
Standard Deviation (%)

If the correlation of returns between the two securities is 0.40, the expected standard deviation of the portfolio is closest to:

entry.title: CFA0159-s12-P_Q3

feedback.neutral:
A is correct.

σ p o r t = w 1 2 σ 1 2 + w 2 2 σ 2 2 + 2 w 1 w 2 C o v ( R 1 R 2 ) = ( 0.3 ) 2 ( 20 % ) 2 + ( 0.7 ) 2 ( 12 % ) 2 + 2 ( 0.3 ) ( 0.7 ) ( − 0.0240 ) = ( 0.3600 % + 0.7056 % − 1.008 % ) 0.5 = ( 0.0576 % ) 0.5 = 2.40 %

entry.itemBody:
A portfolio manager creates the following portfolio:

Security Security Weight (%) Expected
Standard Deviation (%)
1 30 20
2 70 12

If the covariance of returns between the two securities is −0.0240, the expected standard deviation of the portfolio is closest to:

entry.body:
A portfolio manager creates the following portfolio:

Security Security Weight (%) Expected

Standard Deviation (%)
1 30 20
2 70 12
entry.title: Vignette
CFA0159-s12-P_Q4

feedback.neutral: C is correct. A portfolio standard deviation of 14.40% is the weighted average, which is possible only if the correlation between the securities is equal to 1.0.

entry.itemBody: If the standard deviation of the portfolio is 14.40%, the correlation between the two securities is equal to:

entry.title: CFA0159-s12-P_Q7

feedback.neutral: B is correct. A portfolio standard deviation of 14.40% is the weighted average, which is possible only if the correlation between the securities is equal to 1.0. If the correlation coefficient is equal to 1.0, then the covariance must equal 0.0240, calculated as: Cov(R 1,R 2) = ρ12σ1σ2 = (1.0)(20%)(12%) = 2.40% = 0.0240.

entry.itemBody: If the standard deviation of the portfolio is 14.40%, the covariance between the two securities is equal to:

entry.body:
A portfolio manager creates the following portfolio:

Security Expected Annual Return (%) Expected Standard Deviation (%)
1 16 20
2 12 20
entry.title: Vignette
CFA0159-s12-P_Q5

feedback.neutral:
C is correct.

R p = w 1 × R 1 + ( 1   − w 1 ) × R 2 R p = w 1 × 16 % + ( 1 − w 1 ) × 12 % 15 % = 0.75 ( 16 % ) + 0.25 ( 12 % )

entry.itemBody: If the portfolio of the two securities has an expected return of 15%, the proportion invested in Security 1 is:

entry.title: CFA0159-s12-P_Q8

feedback.neutral:
A is correct.

σ p o r t = w 1 2 σ 1 2 + w 2 2 σ 2 2 + 2 w 1 w 2 ρ 1 , 2 σ 1 σ 2 = ( 0.5 ) 2 ( 20 % ) 2 + ( 0.5 ) 2 ( 20 % ) 2 + 2 ( 0.5 ) ( 0.5 ) ( − 0.15 ) ( 20 % ) ( 20 % ) = ( 1.0000 % + 1.0000 % − 0.3000 % ) 0.5 = ( 1.7000 % ) 0.5 = 13.04 %

entry.itemBody: If the correlation of returns between the two securities is −0.15, the expected standard deviation of an equal-weighted portfolio is closest to:

entry.title: CFA0159-s12-P_Q9

feedback.neutral:
B is correct.

σ p o r t = w 1 2 σ 1 2 + w 2 2 σ 2 2 + 2 w 1 w 2 ρ 1 , 2 σ 1 σ 2 = ( 0.5 ) 2 ( 20 % ) 2 + ( 0.5 ) 2 ( 20 % ) 2 + 2 ( 0.5 ) ( 0.5 ) ( 0.00 ) ( 20 % ) ( 20 % ) = ( 1.0000 % + 1.0000 % − 0.0000 % ) 0.5 = ( 2.0000 % ) 0.5 = 14.14 %

entry.itemBody: If the two securities are uncorrelated, the expected standard deviation of an equal-weighted portfolio is closest to:

entry.body:
An analyst has made the following return projections for each of three possible outcomes with an equal likelihood of occurrence:

Asset Outcome 1

(%) 		Outcome 2

(%) 		Outcome 3

(%) 		Expected Return

(%)
1 12 0 6 6
2 12 6 0 6
3 0 6 12 6
entry.title: Vignette
CFA0159-s12-P_Q6

feedback.neutral: C is correct. An equally weighted portfolio of Asset 2 and Asset 3 will have the lowest portfolio standard deviation, because for each outcome, the portfolio has the same expected return (they are perfectly negatively correlated).

entry.itemBody: If the analyst constructs two-asset portfolios that are equally-weighted, which pair of assets has the lowest expected standard deviation?

entry.title: CFA0159-s12-Q10

feedback.neutral: A is correct. An equally weighted portfolio of Asset 1 and Asset 2 has the highest level of volatility of the three pairs. All three pairs have the same expected return; however, the portfolio of Asset 1 and Asset 2 provides the least amount of risk reduction.

entry.itemBody: If the analyst constructs two-asset portfolios that are equally weighted, which pair of assets provides the least amount of risk reduction?

entry.title: CFA0159-s13-Q1

feedback.neutral:
B is correct. The contribution of each individual asset’s variance (or standard deviation) to the portfolio’s volatility decreases as the number of assets in the equally weighted portfolio increases. The contribution of the co-movement measures between the assets increases (i.e., covariance and correlation) as the number of assets in the equally weighted portfolio increases. The following equation for the variance of an equally weighted portfolio illustrates these points:

σ p 2 = σ ¯ 2 N + N − 1 N C O V ¯ = σ ¯ 2 N + N − 1 N ρ ¯   σ ¯ 2 .

entry.itemBody: As the number of assets in an equally-weighted portfolio increases, the contribution of each individual asset’s variance to the volatility of the portfolio:

entry.title: CFA0159-s13-Q2

feedback.neutral:
C is correct. The co-movement measures between the assets increases (i.e., covariance and correlation) as the number of assets in the equally weighted portfolio increases. The contribution of each individual asset’s variance (or standard deviation) to the portfolio’s volatility decreases as the number of assets in the equally weighted portfolio increases. The following equation for the variance of an equally weighted portfolio illustrates these points:

σ p 2 = σ ¯ 2 N + N − 1 N C O V ¯ = σ ¯ 2 N + N − 1 N ρ ¯   σ ¯ 2 .

entry.itemBody: With respect to an equally weighted portfolio made up of a large number of assets, which of the following contributes the most to the volatility of the portfolio?

choices.itemBody: A. Average variance of the individual assets.
B. Standard deviation of the individual assets.
C. Average covariance between all pairs of assets.

entry.title: CFA0159-s13-Q3

feedback.neutral: A is correct. Higher correlations will produce less diversification benefits provided that the other components of the portfolio standard deviation do not change (i.e., the weights and standard deviations of the individual assets).

entry.itemBody: The correlation between assets in a two-asset portfolio increases during a market decline. If there is no change in the proportion of each asset held in the portfolio or the expected standard deviation of the individual assets, the volatility of the portfolio is most likely to:

entry.title: CFA0159-s15-Q1

feedback.neutral: C is correct. The efficient frontier does not account for the risk-free rate. The efficient frontier is the set of all attainable risky assets with the highest expected return for a given level of risk or the lowest amount of risk for a given level of return.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is least accurate? The efficient frontier is the set of all attainable risky assets with the:

choices.itemBody: A. highest expected return for a given level of risk.
B. lowest amount of risk for a given level of return.
C. highest expected return relative to the risk-free rate.

entry.title: CFA0159-s15-Q2

feedback.neutral: C is correct. The global minimum-variance portfolio is the portfolio on the minimum-variance frontier with the lowest standard deviation. Although the portfolio is attainable, when the risk-free asset is considered, the global minimum-variance portfolio is not the optimal risky portfolio.

entry.itemBody: The portfolio on the minimum-variance frontier with the lowest standard deviation is:

entry.title: CFA0159-s15-Q3

feedback.neutral: B is correct. The Markowitz efficient frontier has higher rates of return for a given level of risk. With respect to the minimum-variance portfolio, the Markowitz efficient frontier is the set of portfolios above the global minimum-variance portfolio that dominates the portfolios below the global minimum-variance portfolio.

entry.itemBody: The set of portfolios on the minimum-variance frontier that dominates all sets of portfolios below the global minimum-variance portfolio is the:

choices.itemBody: C. set of optimal risky portfolios.

entry.title: CFA0159-s16-Q6

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The use of leverage and the combination of a risk-free asset and the optimal risky asset will dominate the efficient frontier of risky assets (the Markowitz efficient frontier).

entry.itemBody: The dominant capital allocation line is the combination of the risk-free asset and the:

choices.itemBody: B. levered portfolio of risky assets.

entry.title: CFA0159-s16-Q7

feedback.neutral: B is correct. The CAL dominates the efficient frontier at all points except for the optimal risky portfolio. The ability of the investor to purchase additional amounts of the optimal risky portfolio by borrowing (i.e., buying on margin) at the risk-free rate makes higher rates of return for levels of risk greater than the optimal risky asset possible.

entry.itemBody: Compared to the efficient frontier of risky assets, the dominant capital allocation line has higher rates of return for levels of risk greater than the optimal risky portfolio because of the investor’s ability to:

choices.itemBody: A. lend at the risk-free rate.
B. borrow at the risk-free rate.

entry.title: CFA0159-s17-Q8

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Each individual investor’s optimal mix of the risk-free asset and the optimal risky asset is determined by the investor’s risk preference.

entry.itemBody: With respect to the mean–variance theory, the optimal portfolio is determined by each individual investor’s:

entry.title: ITEM_20170606002
entry.itemBody: The correlation between the historical returns of Stock A and Stock B is 0.75. If the variance of Stock A is 0.16 and the variance of Stock B is 0.09, the covariance of returns of Stock A and Stock B is closest to:

answerFeedback.5007e36d-f0ca-4b71-af01-eafe9c694d30: Incorrect. Variance is used instead of standard deviation. Covariance is incorrectly calculated as 0.75 × 0.16 × 0.09 = 0.0108.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606003
entry.itemBody: The point of tangency between the capital allocation line (CAL) and the efficient frontier of risky assets most likely identifies the:

answerFeedback.5648737a-05e3-476f-9cf1-8e4675261742: Incorrect. The optimal investor portfolio lies at the point of tangency between the investor’s indifference curve and the capital allocation line.
answerFeedback.a9f61ff9-5ace-41d4-be09-86f7fb921369: Correct. The optimal risky portfolio lies at the point of tangency between the capital allocation line and the efficient frontier of risky assets.
answerFeedback.db13171f-cb17-4016-9689-7ff7be9cd93e: Incorrect. The global minimum-variance portfolio is the left-most point on the minimum-variance frontier.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606011
entry.itemBody: Consider a portfolio with two assets. Asset A comprises 25% of the portfolio and has a standard deviation of 17.9%. Asset B comprises 75% of the portfolio and has a standard deviation of 6.2%. If the correlation of these two investments is 0.5, the portfolio standard deviation is closest to:

answerFeedback.6627c7e6-4a25-4062-b7ba-6d66e24a77f1:
Incorrect. It leaves off the correlation term in the equation:

0.25 2 × 0.179 2 + 0.75 2 × 0.062 2 =6.45%
answerFeedback.b8a19486-0a48-4eb4-8594-ceb995297472: Incorrect. It is the weighted average standard deviation of the two assets given: (0.25 × 0.179 + 0.75 × 0.062) = 9.125%.
answerFeedback.fe47834b-39f7-492b-a4ae-6d88c7bcdb83:
Correct. The standard deviation of a two-asset portfolio is given by the square root of the portfolio’s variance:

σ p = w 1 2 σ 1 2 + w 2 2 σ 2 2 +2 w 1 w 2 ρ 1,2 σ 1 σ 2

Using this formula, the existing standard deviation is calculated as follows:

0.252×0.1792+0.752×0.0622+2×0.75×0.25×0.5×0.179×0.062=7.90%

entry.title: ITEM_20170606036
entry.itemBody: A portfolio contains equal weights of two securities having the same standard deviation. If the correlation between the returns of the two securities was to decrease, the portfolio risk would most likely:

answerFeedback.50360a18-695f-42c7-80e7-7c769fc978b8:
Correct. The formula for the return standard deviation (risk) of a two asset portfolio is

σ p = w 1 2 σ 1 2 + w 2 2 σ 2 2 +2 w 1 w 2 Cov( R 1 , R 2 )

The formula for portfolio risk shows that portfolio risk decreases as the correlation decreases.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606057
entry.itemBody:
The covariance of the assets in the following portfolio is closest to:

  Asset 1 Asset 2 Asset 1
vs. Asset 2
Correlation --- --- 0.8
Portfolio weight 0.6 0.4 ---
Variance 3.5% 1.5% ---

answerFeedback.0fbcf11f-8bf0-4865-bc9f-31f58f8ac243:
Correct. The covariance is calculated from the standard deviations of the two assets and their correlation. The portfolio weights are not relevant.

Cov = ρ1,2 × σ1 × σ2

 = ρ 1,2 × var 1 × var 2

 = 0.8× 3.5% × 1.5%

= 1.8%
answerFeedback.1119e564-a925-41ff-906b-f1d788d0bd13:
Incorrect. The covariance is calculated from the standard deviations of the two assets and their correlation. The portfolio weights are not relevant.

 = ρ1,2 × w1 × σ1 × w2 × σ2

 = ρ 1,2 × w 1 × var 1 × w 2 × var 2

 = 0.8×0.6× 3.5% ×0.4× 1.5%

= 0.4%
answerFeedback.afda3bf9-ec60-4c5c-9630-b2bc1f760319:
Incorrect. The covariance is not calculated solely from the standard deviations of the two assets. It also requires one use their correlation.

 = σ1 × σ2

 = var 1 × var 2

 = 3.5% × 1.5%

= 2.3%

entry.title: ITEM_20170606058
entry.itemBody: When considering a portfolio that is optimal for one investor, a second investor with a higher risk aversion would most likely:

answerFeedback.6f59103a-4bd4-4709-9168-cac9f93b0d85: Correct. Utility has two terms: the expected return and a negative term based on the portfolio risk weighted by risk aversion. For an identical portfolio, the investor with a higher risk aversion (A) would calculate a lower utility (U).U=E(r) -12Aσ
answerFeedback.743c808d-bdc0-4fa8-9875-68ad3534dff5: Incorrect. The expected variance of the portfolio is fixed. It does not change based on the preferences of different investors.
answerFeedback.c0ff1c87-c599-43eb-b746-40670375aef8: Incorrect. The expected return of the portfolio is fixed. It does not change based on the preferences of different investors.

choices.itemBody: A. expect a higher variance for the portfolio.
B. derive a lower utility from the portfolio.
C. have a lower return expectation for the portfolio.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606059
entry.itemBody:
Based on the following historical data, which is closest to the standard deviation for the two-asset portfolio shown in the table?

  Asset A Asset B Asset A
and B
Standard deviation 4.7% 7.7% --
Portfolio weight 0.4 0.6 --
Correlation -- -- 0.3

answerFeedback.08fd63ec-147f-4bcb-a972-a0aa9b8a030d:
Correct. The standard deviation of a two-asset portfolio is calculated as follows:

σp = w 1 2 × σ 1 2 + w 2 2 × σ 2 2 +2 w 1 w 2 ρ 1,2 σ 1 σ 2

 = 0.4 2 ×4.7 % 2 + 0.6 2 ×7.7 % 2 +2×0.4×0.6×0.3×4.7%×7.7%

 = 5.5%
answerFeedback.2865cef3-51f5-40fc-8773-28f7f06366d5:
Incorrect. This is the portfolio standard deviation when the asset correlation is ignored or set equal to zero.

w 1 2 × σ 1 2 + w 2 2 × σ 2 2 = 0.4 2 ×4.7 % 2 + 0.6 2 ×7.7 % 2 =5.0%
answerFeedback.c326042c-8876-4f3a-b039-624dbd9d7cf2: Incorrect. This is the simple weighted average of the standard deviations of the assets: w1 × σ1 + w2 × σ2 = 0.4 × 4.7% + 0.6 × 7.7% = 6.5%.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606060
entry.itemBody: All else held constant, a lower correlation between the assets in a portfolio most likely results in higher:

answerFeedback.86ac3dfb-91ae-496b-be74-259ac2bcb388: Incorrect. The portfolio return does not change with lower correlation between assets, as long as the expected returns of the individual assets are unchanged.
answerFeedback.88229311-19de-40e9-be58-146d06df9446: Incorrect. The portfolio volatility would decrease, all else being equal, when the correlation between assets decreases.
answerFeedback.bd2605ce-5edc-4e15-bd25-530ffc88a7da: Correct. An investor may achieve diversification by combining two assets that are not perfectly correlated. This diversification increases as the correlation decreases.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606062
entry.itemBody: When constructing the optimal portfolios for investors with different risk preferences, the investor with the higher risk aversion is most likely to have a:

answerFeedback.4e3c159c-6a23-48d0-ad9d-31a779dd3d07: Incorrect. The indifference curve for a more risk averse investor steepens rather than flattens.
answerFeedback.98d4d4a0-e0ac-40ca-a0fb-4ed73c648b9f: Incorrect. The capital allocation line is fixed. It does not change based on the preferences of different investors.
answerFeedback.b8991033-6000-4a2d-bfbb-ec8c5104e1e9: Correct. The optimal portfolio is identified as the point at which the capital allocation line (CAL) is tangential to the investor’s indifference curve. As investor risk aversion increases, the optimal portfolio slides down the CAL to a point of lower expected risk and lower expected return.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606097
entry.itemBody: John Smith is given two investment options. Option A is a payment with a 50% chance of getting $100 and a 50% chance of getting $0. Option B is a guaranteed payment of $50. If Smith chooses Option A over Option B, his risk preference is best described as risk:

answerFeedback.7397ceb1-9498-4c8d-b242-a646a1d683cd: Incorrect. A risk-averse person would prefer a lower risk profile given the same expected return.
answerFeedback.b4261433-fe35-41f1-af7f-5499042d12c5: Correct. Both options have the same expected return of $50. Option A, however, has a higher risk (standard deviation) than Option B. Therefore, John Smith’s risk preference is that of risk seeking.
answerFeedback.f4553128-d21a-4cbd-8350-a65866d3fb01: Incorrect. A risk-neutral person would be indifferent about the risk profile of the outcome.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606100
entry.itemBody:
Which of the following portfolios of risky assets is most likely the global minimum-variance portfolio?

Portfolio Expected Return Standard Deviation
A 5% 20%
B 8% 33%
C 3% 20%

answerFeedback.0728ac43-4dfc-47b3-acb4-f60016223376: Incorrect. It has a lower expected return while having the same variance as portfolio A. It is unlikely to be located on the minimum-variance frontier.
answerFeedback.c3f3c8bf-8ea6-4925-91a7-ee6b830235ec: Correct. The global minimum-variance portfolio is the left-most point on the minimum-variance frontier among all portfolios of risky assets. Portfolios A and C have the same standard deviation, but Portfolio A dominates Portfolio C because of a higher return.
answerFeedback.f55cb12b-2812-4420-9270-3c68eae02843: Incorrect. It has a higher variance than portfolio A.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606051
entry.itemBody: If Investor A has a lower risk aversion coefficient than Investor B, on the capital allocation line, will Investor B’s optimal portfolio most likely have a higher expected return?

answerFeedback.454e25c9-a084-4fbc-9232-b71a91ecf39e: Correct. Investor B has a higher risk aversion coefficient, thus a lower risk tolerance and a lower expected return on the capital allocation line.
answerFeedback.b1b03d1b-f0f4-4bf6-acd3-d3df84be7793: Incorrect. Investor A has a higher expected return on the capital allocation line.
answerFeedback.c1a80f88-28b4-43b1-9b15-4dd2e7f7ac50: Incorrect. Investor B has lower risk tolerance.

choices.itemBody: B. No, because Investor B has a higher risk tolerance
C. No, because Investor B has a lower risk tolerance
